_link.title: I can explain why fusion requires extreme temperatures

toLevel2.stem: What temperature is required for nuclear fusion to occur?
options: Millions to hundreds of millions of degrees Celsius
toLevel2.explanation: Fusion requires temperatures of 10-100+ million degrees Celsius to overcome electrostatic repulsion between nuclei.

toLevel2.stem: What force must be overcome for fusion to occur?
toLevel2.explanation: Atomic nuclei are positively charged and repel each other. Extreme energy is needed to overcome this repulsion.

toLevel2.stem: Why do nuclei repel each other?
options: They both have positive electric charge
toLevel2.explanation: All nuclei contain protons which are positively charged. Like charges repel each other.

toLevel2.stem: What provides the energy for nuclei to overcome their repulsion?
options: Extremely high kinetic energy from high temperatures
toLevel2.explanation: High temperatures give particles extreme kinetic energy, allowing them to collide fast enough to overcome repulsion.

toLevel2.stem: What is the Coulomb barrier in nuclear fusion?
options: The electrostatic repulsion that nuclei must overcome to fuse
toLevel2.explanation: The Coulomb barrier is the energy barrier created by electrostatic repulsion between positively charged nuclei.

toLevel2.stem: Fusion requires temperatures of [[millions]] of degrees to give nuclei enough [[kinetic energy]] to overcome repulsion.
toLevel2.explanation: Extreme temperatures translate to extreme kinetic energy, which is needed to overcome the Coulomb barrier.

toLevel2.stem: Nuclei repel each other because they both have [[positive]] charge, creating [[electrostatic]] repulsion.
toLevel2.explanation: Protons in nuclei are positive, and like charges repel according to Coulomb's law.

toLevel2.stem: The [[Coulomb barrier]] is the energy barrier that must be overcome for [[fusion]] to occur.
toLevel2.explanation: The Coulomb barrier is created by electrostatic repulsion between positively charged nuclei.

toLevel2.stem: Fusion can occur at room temperature under normal conditions.
toLevel2.explanation: False. Fusion requires millions of degrees to overcome the electrostatic repulsion between nuclei.

toLevel2.stem: Atomic nuclei repel each other because they are both positively charged.
toLevel2.explanation: True. Nuclei contain protons which are positive. Like charges repel, creating the Coulomb barrier.

toLevel3.stem: Why is the temperature required for D-T fusion lower than for p-p fusion?
options: Heavier isotopes have higher quantum tunneling probability at lower energies
toLevel3.explanation: Larger nuclei have higher tunneling probability. D-T requires ~100 million degrees; p-p needs billions.

toLevel3.stem: How does quantum tunneling help fusion occur?
options: It allows nuclei to pass through the Coulomb barrier without having the full classical energy
toLevel3.explanation: Quantum mechanics allows a probability of tunneling through energy barriers, enabling fusion at lower temperatures than classically required.

toLevel3.stem: Why does higher temperature increase fusion rate?
options: More nuclei have enough energy to overcome or tunnel through the Coulomb barrier
toLevel3.explanation: Higher temperature means more particles have sufficient energy for fusion or tunneling, increasing reaction probability.

toLevel3.stem: What happens to matter at fusion temperatures?
options: Atoms are completely ionised, forming plasma
toLevel3.explanation: At millions of degrees, electrons are stripped from atoms, creating plasma where bare nuclei can interact.

toLevel3.stem: Why can't solid materials contain fusion plasma directly?
options: No material can withstand millions of degrees without vaporising
toLevel3.explanation: Fusion temperatures far exceed the melting point of any known material. Plasma must be contained without physical contact.

toLevel3.stem: How does the strong nuclear force relate to fusion temperature requirements?
options: Nuclei must get close enough for the strong force to overcome electrostatic repulsion
The strong force increases with temperature
toLevel3.explanation: The strong nuclear force only acts at very short range (~1 fm). Nuclei must overcome Coulomb repulsion to get that close.

toLevel3.stem: Quantum [[tunneling]] allows fusion at lower temperatures by letting nuclei pass through the [[Coulomb barrier]].
toLevel3.explanation: Quantum tunneling enables nuclei to penetrate the energy barrier without having the full classical energy requirement.

toLevel3.stem: At fusion temperatures, matter becomes [[plasma]] with [[electrons]] stripped from nuclei.
toLevel3.explanation: Plasma is the fourth state of matter where atoms are fully ionised.

toLevel3.stem: The strong nuclear force only acts at [[short range]] (~1 fm), requiring nuclei to overcome [[electrostatic]] repulsion first.
toLevel3.explanation: The strong force binds nuclei but only at femtometre distances; Coulomb repulsion must be overcome to reach this range.

toLevel3.stem: Quantum tunneling allows some fusion to occur even when nuclei don't have enough classical energy to overcome the Coulomb barrier.
toLevel3.explanation: True. Quantum mechanics provides a probability for particles to tunnel through barriers they couldn't classically surmount.

toLevel4.stem: Calculate the approximate kinetic energy (in eV) of a particle at 100 million K. (Use E = 3/2 kT, k = 8.617×10⁻⁵ eV/K)
toLevel4.explanation: E = 1.5 × 8.617×10⁻⁵ × 10⁸ ≈ 12,900 eV ≈ 13 keV. This is typical thermal energy at fusion temperatures.

toLevel4.stem: Why do fusion reactors use D-T fuel rather than hydrogen-hydrogen?
options: D-T requires 'only' 100 million degrees; H-H needs billions of degrees
toLevel4.explanation: D-T has a larger tunneling cross-section at achievable temperatures. H-H fusion occurs in stars due to enormous pressure and time.

toLevel4.stem: A plasma has average particle energy of 10 keV. Estimate its temperature.
How does increasing plasma density affect fusion rate?
options: Higher density means more collisions per second, increasing fusion rate
toLevel4.explanation: Fusion rate depends on collision frequency, which increases with particle density (n₁ × n₂ in rate equation).

toLevel4.stem: Why is the Lawson criterion important for fusion reactors?
options: It defines the minimum n×T×τ needed for energy breakeven
toLevel4.explanation: Lawson criterion (density × temperature × confinement time) must exceed a threshold for net energy production.

toLevel4.stem: Compare energy confinement: How do magnetic and inertial approaches achieve fusion conditions?
options: Magnetic uses long confinement at lower density; inertial uses extreme density for nanoseconds
toLevel4.explanation: Magnetic confinement holds plasma for seconds at lower density; ICF compresses fuel to extreme density for nanoseconds.

toLevel4.stem: If the Coulomb barrier for D-T is about 400 keV, why can fusion occur at 10-20 keV average energy?
options: Quantum tunneling and the high-energy tail of the Maxwell distribution allow some particles to fuse
toLevel4.explanation: Not all particles need 400 keV; tunneling enables fusion below barrier energy, and some particles in the thermal distribution have higher energies.

toLevel4.stem: The Lawson criterion requires sufficient [[density]] × temperature × [[confinement time]] for net energy gain.
toLevel4.explanation: The triple product nTτ must exceed a threshold for fusion to produce more energy than it consumes.

toLevel4.stem: Magnetic confinement uses [[long]] confinement times at lower density; inertial confinement uses [[extreme density]] for nanoseconds.
toLevel4.explanation: Different approaches achieve the Lawson criterion through different combinations of density and time.

toLevel4.stem: Quantum [[tunneling]] and the high-energy [[tail]] of the Maxwell distribution enable fusion below the classical Coulomb barrier.
toLevel4.explanation: Some particles have higher than average energy, and tunneling allows fusion even below the barrier.

toLevel5.stem: Analyze why the Sun can sustain fusion at 15 million K while reactors need 100+ million K.
options: The Sun's enormous gravitational pressure compensates for lower temperature; reactors lack such pressure
toLevel5.explanation: Solar core pressure (~250 billion atm) dramatically increases collision rate, compensating for lower per-particle energy.

toLevel5.stem: Evaluate the relationship between fusion cross-section and temperature.
options: Cross-section increases sharply with temperature up to a peak, then slowly decreases
toLevel5.explanation: Fusion cross-section (σ) increases with energy until quantum effects cause it to plateau and slowly decline at very high energies.

toLevel5.stem: Compare the roles of temperature versus density in achieving fusion conditions.
options: Both are essential: temperature overcomes Coulomb barrier; density provides sufficient collision frequency
toLevel5.explanation: High temperature is necessary but not sufficient; adequate density ensures enough reactions occur for energy production.

toLevel5.stem: How does the Maxwell-Boltzmann distribution affect fusion reactor design?
options: Only the high-energy tail particles fuse, so reactors must account for energy distribution, not just average temperature
toLevel5.explanation: Fusion primarily occurs from the high-energy tail of the distribution, requiring understanding of statistical mechanics.

toLevel5.stem: Analyze why achieving ignition is more difficult than just reaching fusion temperature.
options: Energy losses (radiation, conduction, convection) must be overcome by fusion heating for self-sustaining reaction
toLevel5.explanation: Ignition requires fusion power to exceed all energy losses so the plasma sustains itself without external heating.

toLevel5.stem: Evaluate the impact of plasma instabilities on maintaining fusion temperatures.
options: Instabilities cause energy losses and can disrupt confinement, requiring active stabilisation
toLevel5.explanation: Plasma instabilities are a major challenge, causing energy to leak from the confined region and potentially ending fusion conditions.

toLevel5.stem: Compare the temperature requirements for different fusion fuel cycles (D-T, D-D, p-B11).
options: D-T: ~100M K; D-D: ~400M K; p-B11: ~1 billion K due to higher Coulomb barriers
toLevel5.explanation: Heavier nuclei and higher charges increase Coulomb barriers, requiring proportionally higher temperatures for fusion.

toLevel5.stem: How do superconducting magnets enable higher fusion performance?
options: Stronger magnetic fields provide better plasma confinement, allowing higher temperatures and densities
They have no effect on fusion
toLevel5.explanation: High-temperature superconductors enable stronger magnetic fields, improving confinement and enabling higher-performance fusion plasmas.

toLevel5.stem: The Sun compensates for lower temperature with enormous [[gravitational pressure]], while reactors must achieve higher [[temperatures]] instead.
toLevel5.explanation: Different approaches to meeting fusion conditions: the Sun uses pressure; terrestrial reactors use higher temperatures.

toLevel5.stem: Plasma [[instabilities]] cause energy losses and require active [[stabilisation]] to maintain fusion conditions.
toLevel5.explanation: Controlling plasma instabilities is one of the major engineering challenges in fusion reactor development.
